Was playing with the decal tool. Select the decal, select bullethole and then put the bullet in a little mountain. The same happen with the playerfoot...Is a known bug?

data.title: Include navigation and testing modules by default

milestone.description: This version will focus on processing two of the major outstanding pull requests, James Urquhart's [TorqueScript interpreter improvements](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/81) and Tim Condon's [GUI additions](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/545). Along with that we'll be bringing in lots of other TS-related enhancements, adding unit tests for TS to make sure we don't break your games, and processing even more of the outstanding issue list.

data.body:
- They are both useful and can easily be turned off.
- Navigation being off by default causes problems with the navmesh editor, which is _included_ by default, but nonfunctional unless the module is included.
- Navigation can kind of be considered a stock feature.

The only problem is that I see no way to do something equivalent with the project generator. We could add `includeModule` to the Templates' default config files, but this won't show up in the manager UI when you create a new project.

data.title: OpenGL VBO Crash
data.body:
Randomly during GUI rendering, a fatal assert is thrown saying that inside of GFXDrawUtil::drawBitmapStretchSR(), "Cannot access verts from an unlocked vertex buffer!!!" Yet, the vertex buffer handle has called .lock() before setting the points. verts[0].points.set() will throw a EXE_BAD_ACCESS

Has anybody seen this on windows or linux OpenGL during testing?

Will have to do some investigation...
- Using the OpenGL 3.2 CORE profile
- Mac OS 10.10.2 "yosemite"
- Intel Iris Pro OpenGL Engine OpenGL V 4.1
- 1536MB video ram

Although the branch is very similar, the only modifications on here is to get it to compile and run on OSX basic lighting.
https://github.com/JeffProgrammer/Torque3D/tree/mac-gl32-merge-dev

Crash is here: https://github.com/JeffProgrammer/Torque3D/blob/mac-gl32-merge-dev/Engine/source/gfx/gfxDrawUtil.cpp#L385

data.title: Memory Growth with UTF16 cache
data.body:
With TORQUE_ENABLE_UTF16_CACHE enabled, every string you happen to convert to UTF16 will be inserted into a cache (sgUTF16Cache). There is however a big problem with this, as this applies to almost every string you happen to use in the GUI and also most of the filesystem functions.

If for instance you press and hold down the "a" key in the console, a string of "a" characters will get converted to UTF16 and will be placed in the cache. On the next frame, you will have extra "a" characters appended to the string which will then be converted to UTF16 and be placed in the cache. This will go on and on with the size of the inserted string growing exponentially, eventually depleting available memory.

Of course, you may think "Why is this a problem? Of course filling a text box with the letter "a" will eventually deplete memory!". However the problem is Torque only frees memory from the UTF16 cache when it quits. Every single version of the "a" string will be stuck in there ("aa", "aaa", "aaaa", etc).

This may also be a problem during gameplay. For instance lets say you have a timer or score counter in your GUI which increments. It's entirely possible you could run out of memory or even addressable memory depending on what happens.

data.title: Fix all initializer list ordering
data.body: There are a ton of warnings generated by `gcc`'s `-Wreorder`. The warning's meaning is explained [here](http://blog.kutny.net/2014/07/14/c-member-initializer-list-fallacy-a-k-a-wreorder/). Might not be any actual bugs, but it'd be nice to be on the safe side.

data.title: Clean CMAKE modules
data.body:
I need some feedback on CMAKE.

This PR make full modular and more easy to mantain, but have 2 problems:
- First generation dont have a complete cache for all modules, this cause get invalid build. We need to generate at least 2 times.
- Some complex configurations need set data after targer is defined. Actually is handled by a second module file... i dont like this.

My idea to fix the problems is each module have `if sections` for handle diferent configuration passes:

```
# test module

if( MODULE_PHASE_OPTIONS )
    option(TORQUE_THIS_IS_A_TEST "This is a test" OFF)
endif()

if( MODULE_PHASE_BUILDING )
    addPathRec("${srcDir}/blabla")
endif()

if( MODULE_PHASE_TARGET )
    set_property(TARGET ${PROJECT_NAME} PROPERTY OUTPUT_NAME_${CONF} ${PROJECT_NAME}_${SUFFIX})
endif()
```

What you think? 
Complicate too much module files?

data.title: Cmake unity build
data.body:
This branch implements support for a [unity build configuration](https://cheind.wordpress.com/2009/12/10/reducing-compilation-time-unity-builds/), generated by CMake when
`TORQUE_UNIFIED_BUILD`
is enabled.

Build timings from my 4 core / 4 thread 2.6 GHz machine:

| config | build time |
| --- | --- |
| debug build | 3.2 min |
| debug build (unity) | 32 sec |
| release build | 3.6 min |
| release build (unity) | 1 min |

The generated release executables are slightly larger, probably because the compiler is able to inline more aggressively.

There are some downsides to the unity build, mainly increased chance of name collisions between macros and names from anonymous namespaces. So you need to exercise a bit more discretion when doing "using namespace" or using anonymous namespaces or #defines. Also I've noticed that Visual Studio can get confused and produce errors when switching the same solution between the normal and unity configuration, so I recommend having out-of-source build directories that are dedicated to a particular config.

The unity build is currently disabled by default. My plan is to add a CI build that compiles the unity configuration so we can easily see breakages. Then, if people are keen on the idea, we can eventually switch to defaulting to the unified build. If not, I would still like to get this code in the tree so we can start using it downstream :)

A lot of the changes in this branch are general cleanup that are a happy side effect of fixing the unity build - fixing include guards, removing dead or duplicated functions, and trimming unneeded declarations and "using" directives. I tried to separate these into commits that are more or less atomic. The commit where (most of) the conflicting identifiers were renamed is here: 02e6ada

I tried to test as many configurations as possible, but things like Oculus/Hydra/etc support I wasn't able to test. If anyone is building with those configs, it would be great if they could try the branch any let me know if it's broken for them :)

data.title: Pull Request #1026 broke the console stack

milestone.description: This version will focus on processing two of the major outstanding pull requests, James Urquhart's [TorqueScript interpreter improvements](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/81) and Tim Condon's [GUI additions](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/545). Along with that we'll be bringing in lots of other TS-related enhancements, adding unit tests for TS to make sure we don't break your games, and processing even more of the outstanding issue list.

data.body:
There have been numerous reports that the console stack is throwing out asserts in the development branch. I've tracked it down to a certain pull request of mine, PR 1026 (https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/1026). Intended to fix issue #976 .

It seems while it fixed the reported issue, it has the unintended side-effect of not cleaning the stack out correctly during future function calls.

data.title: RigidShape Does Not Collide With GroundPlane
data.body:
RigidShape appears broken. When spawning the boulder it falls at warp speed 9 with no apparent physics/resistance and has no collision when it hits anything and just keeps going. Worked in v2.5+, not in v3.6+.

To repeat just spawn a rigidShape->BouncingBoulder in a mission/level and watch it plummet at the speed of Sanic the Hedgehog.
